threats.title: Distributed Denial of Service
threats.description: A DDoS attack could disable or severely hamper the performance of the service.
threats.mitigation:
Multiple
- Configuration of DDoS capabilities in AWS (AWS Shield) or similar

threats.title: Denial of Service
threats.description: The service could be compromised (disabled or performance-affected) through the exploitation of a vulnerability.
threats.mitigation:
Multiple
- service upgrades
- patching
- auto-scaling
- immutable services

Infrastructure controls
- WAF
- Anti-malware (if appropriate)

threats.title: OWASP API1:2023 Broken Object Level Authorisation
threats.description:
Attackers can exploit API endpoints that are vulnerable to broken object-level authorisation by manipulating the ID of an object that is sent within the request. Object IDs can be anything from sequential integers, UUIDs, or generic strings. Regardless of the data type, they are easy to identify in the request target (path or query string parameters), request headers, or even as part of the request payload. Unauthorised access to other usersâ€™ objects can result in data disclosure to unauthorised parties, data loss, or data manipulation. Under certain circumstances, unauthorised access to objects can also lead to full account takeover.

Also see Mitre Att&ck T1528 Steal Application Access Token
threats.mitigation:
- Implement a proper authorisation mechanism that relies on the user policies and hierarchy.
- Use the authorisation mechanism to check if the logged-in user has access to perform the requested action on the record in every function that uses an input from the client to access a record in the database.
- Prefer the use of random and unpredictable values as GUIDs for records' IDs.
- Write tests to evaluate the vulnerability of the authorisation mechanism. Do not deploy changes that make the tests fail.

References:

https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Authorization_Cheat_Sheet.html
https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/Authorization_Testing_Automation_Cheat_Sheet.html

threats.title: OWASP API8:2023 and AO5:2021 Security Misconfiguration
threats.description: Attackers will often attempt to find unpatched flaws, common endpoints, services running with insecure default configurations, or unprotected files and directories to gain unauthorised access or knowledge of the system. Most of this is public knowledge and exploits may be available.
threats.mitigation:
The API life cycle should include:
- A repeatable hardening process leading to fast and easy deployment of a properly locked down environment
- A task to review and update configurations across the entire API stack. The review should include: orchestration files, API components, and cloud services (e.g. S3 bucket permissions)
- An automated process to continuously assess the effectiveness of the configuration and settings in all environments

threats.title: Data Loss
threats.description: PII or other sensitive information on users device could be compromised BY our compromised service.
threats.mitigation:
Multiple
- Preventative and Detective security measures applied to service.
    - CSRF/CSS mitigations applied
